THE NEWS LET:ER
VOL. XVI, NO. 2.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 16, 1911.

WEDDING BELLS FOR LYNN

HAZING IS ON THE WANE

Popular Hopkins Football Coach to Be
Married on Saturday—McCabe
and Stollenwerck Ushers.

Sophomores Are Treating the Freshmen
Kindly—Latter Wear Hats and
Ride in Elevator.

Successful in the game of love,
as well as in football, Thomas Herbert Lynn, Yale, '09, will lead to
altar Miss Myra Kincaid McCormick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Seth Thomas McCormick,on Saturday night, October 21, at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Williamsport,
Pa. A reception will follow immediately after the wedding ceremony at the city home of the bride's
parents in Williamsport.
Hopkins football players, in particular, and all Hopkins students,
in general, are interested in this
wedding, because of Mr. Lynn's
connection with Hopkins during
the last two years in the. capacity
of coach of the football team. Coach
Lynn was chosen by the Athletic
Board in the spring of 1910 to succeed Mr. Gill as head coach of the
football team. He was ,highly
recommended to the University by
Walter Camp, the dean of American football, and Ted Coy, the captain of teh Yale championship team
of 1909.
Coach Lynn was a member of the
Yale 'Varsity squad for three years,
and was considered one of the most
reliable and one of the headiest of
the Yale players. The Yale coaches
had unbounded confidence in him.
When he assumed the direction of
the Hopkins team last fall, prospects were not over bright, but
with the assistance of Dr. Paul
Sieber, he succeeded in turning out
the best eleven that ever represented
the Black and Blue on the gridiron.
Although many of last year's men
Will not play this season, Coach
Lynn is hard at work, and before
the home games come round, he
can be depended upon to have a
team on the field which will be able
1. to uphold the reputations made by
the .teams of the last two seasons.
Miss McCormick is a "darling,
and just the sweetest thing that
ever lived," according to stray remarks dropped by Coach Lynn from
time to time. He even goes to the
extent of praising her in foreign
languages and was heard once to
exclaim: "Ciel est toi," as he licked
a postage stamp on the envelope
of a letter to his future better half.
Miss 1\ICormick is a graduate of
the Ogontz School, of Philadelphia,
Pa. Her -family is well known in
Northern Pennsylvania, and her
father is one of the leading lawyers
of the State.

With the exception of one or two
attempts to make the underclassmen sing and practice yells, the
sophomores have so far kept in the
background, and there has been
little real hazing. On Wednesday,
a brief concert, which was interrupted by the appearance of the
police, was given on Howard street
and on Thursday, rumor had it, that
several freshies were taken to a
back yard in the vicinity of the University and turned into scrubwomen.
Both were very harmless forms of
discipline.
But meanwhile, contrary to all
Hopkins traditions, the freshmen
wear their hats in McCoy Hall,
ride in the elevator and swagger
around with senior-like assurance.
There has not even been a classrush to dampen their boyish affrontery.
The musical program which was
given on Wednesday at noon, was.
brief but excellent. Six of the biggist freshmen in the class were
taken to the curbstone in front of
the buildings of the Geological
Survey, on'
Howard street, divested
of their coats and hats, given song
books and told to warble. They
warbled obediently and soon a large
crowd gathered. Two policemen,
who were at the corner of Franklin
and Howard streets, saw the commotion and heard the noise. They
started for the scene, but when they
arrived, the prisoners had been hurried around on Monument street,
where a further program was rendered. This, according to some accounts, was unsatisfactory, and as
a consequence, the offending freshmen were ducked in the fountain.
The, scrubbing stunt took place
on Thursday. The three freshmen
'who were captured, were made to
don aprons and scrub. When they
had concluded their tasks, the sophomores formed themselves into
a mock faculty and awarded degrees, implying proficiency in the
art of removing dust and ashes and
polishing floors.

All the Hopkins players enjoyed
the trip greatly, and they were
unanimous in declaring it to be the
best that had ever been arranged
for the Hopkins team. The wisdom
of going on to New York the day
before was shown by the result of
the game. The players were much
fresher than they would have been
if they had had to make the tiresome journey the morning Of the
game.
After the game was over, the
players were allowed to go about
the city and see the sights. Several
theatre parties were arranged. Captain Fulton, Belt, Gillet, Catlin, Dorsey and Manager Getz had a box
at the Knickerbocker Theatre and
saw "The Siren," the latest production by the authors of "The Dollar
Princess."
A number of Hopkins rooters
were present at the game. Messrs.
Penniman, McCabe, Stollenwerck,.
Lloyd and Huck, accompanied the
team to New York. Messrs. Berry
V\Taters, B. F. Pedrick, Brooke Bird
and several other alumni also were
on hand to cheer the team to victory.
Hopkins Scholars Announced.

The four Hopkins scholarships
given annually to the four freshmen
who stand highest in a competitive
examination were awarded last Friday to the following students: F. C.
Tarr, C. I. Uhler, M. Barroway, and
C. Scharf.
All of these men prepared for
Hopkins at the Baltimore City College.
In Senator Robert 1\1. La Follette's autobiography, which is appearing serially in the American
Maga.sine, he confesses that while
at the University of Wisconsin, he
edited the University Press. Senator La Follette should be classed,
therefore, with Professor Greene,
Ex-President Theodore Roosevelt,
Dr. French, and the other famous
men who edited student publications
while at college.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 16, 1911
Lacrosse Relations With Mount
Washington.

In another column, THE NEwsLETTER prints today a letter in
which the writer urges that the
lacrosse management arrange a
game with Mount Washington and
advances many reasons why such a
contest would be for the best interests of lacrosse in Baltimore, besides providing one of the best
drawing cards and money makers
of the season.
Our experience in games with
Mount Washington in the past has
not been the best and a great deal
of ill-feeling between the adherents
Of the two teams has been shown.
Recent overtures, however, on the
part of the members of the Mount
Washington team, make it seem
probable that if a game were ar• ranged for this year different conditions would exist. At any rate,
when the Hopkins management is
making up its schedule, it would
do no. harm, and a great deal of
good, to talk with representatives
of the Hillmen, and if the game
were tried this year as an experiment, with the understanding that
'if ill-feeling developed, there would
never be another contest, the students and club-men would be on
their guard against any hostile
demonstrations on the field.
We invite expressions of opinion
on the subject.
Have the Class-Rush at Homewood.

- Up until last year, one of the exciting features of the first few days
at Hopkins was the annual classrush between the freshmen and
sophomores, which was held in the
University cage, under the direction
of a committee of seniors. The
time for the fracas was announced,
and freshmen and sophomores,large
and small, were herded in the cage,
and given time to don suitable
clothes. Then each class was lined

up on opposite ends of the track,
and at the given signal, there was
the rush, the ensuing rough-house
and 'the flush of victory for one
class.
Sometimes the ground was covered with. tan-bark; Sometimes
not, and then there was more fun.
The faculty and non-interested students used to stand in the gallery
to see the fray, and class-spirit had
an opportunity to show itself in
a mild and good-natured fashion.
That the rush must be held during
the first week, was one of Hopkins'
traditions.
Last year, however, the University authorities, with a certain amount
of justification, decided that the
cage was too small and the risk
of injury too great. Accordingly,
Homewood was decided upon, and
the two classes clashed between the
halves of a football game.
The same thing should be done
this year. Saturday, October 21, the
date for the game with the Maryland Agricultural College, is a good
time, and it should be arranged for
the rush to take place then. It
would be an excellent feature to
draw a crowd to see the game, and
would be following the precedent
set last year.
THF: NMS-LETTER suggests that
the football management and the
class presidents get together and
see if whether this plan is not feasible.

Items of Interest Concerning the "Loyal

Pittsburgh Gazette-Times.

Ph.D., '99, resigned his position as
assistant to the Superintendent of
Public Instruction in Baltimore,and
is now in New York with the United
States Fidelity and Guaranty Company.
Morris A. Soper, A. B., '93, is
running for Attorney-General on
the Republican ticket in Maryland.
Dr. William H. Maltbie, Ph.D.,
'95, formerly professor of mathematics in Goucher College, is one
of the Republican candidates for
the House of Delegates in Maryland.
Stanley Meade Reynolds, A. B.,
'o8, is now a father and a reporter
on the Baltimore News. He once
edited THE NEWS-LETTER, another
example of the tremendous opportunities which student editors possess.

what it the best excuse to offer an instructor when I am unprepared?

Tell him that you ordered the
book through the new book department. This, without further explanation, will be sufficient. This excuse should be good for a month

I will give you another.

To the Editor of THE

12, 1911.

NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—THE NEWS-LETTER has
been doing good work in the past,
and no doubt will continue to do
good work in time to come. However, I think that it might be well
to remind the readers that a college paper can be more successful
if they would send, from time to
time, friendly criticisms and suggestions to the editors. Certainly
the editors would take the criticisms
as they are intended, and endeavor
to* carry out all good suggestions.
I do not intend simply to make
this suggestion and then fail "to
practice what I preach." It has
often occurred to me that THE
NEWS-LETTER, early in the football
season, might run in short accounts
of the new men out for the team.
All of us would like to know what
teams the new graduate and medical men played on formerly, what
they did, etc. Because of such
knowledge, those attending the University would be able to watch the
games with greater interest, since
they would be acquainted with the
names and the standing of the individual players. I am, sir,

Opportunity for Students Who Are Interested in International Arbitration.
Rogers Third Last Year.

Announcement. is made by the
Lake Mohonk Conference on International Arbitration, that a prize
of $mo is offered for the best essay
on "International Arbitration," by
an _undergraduate man student of
any college or university in the
United States or Canada. This is
the contest which was won by Mr.
L. B., Bobbitt, A.B., 1911,two years
ago. It is given by Mr. Chester
Dewitt Pugsley, of Peekskill, N. Y.
(Harvard, '09). The judges this
year are: Hon. Oscar S. Straus,
member of the Hague Court, formerly ambassador to Turkey; Hon.
Elmer Ellsworth Brown, Chancellor of New York University, and
Rear-Admiral Charles H. Stockton,
1.nited States Navy, retired.
The contest closes March 15,
1912. The following conditions are
announced :
Each essay should show an understanding of the nature and history
of international arbitration apart
from and in connection with the
Hague Cohferences and Hague
Court, and may also refer to (or,
'subject to the above requirement,
emphasize) such subjects as the
Permanent Court of Arbitration,
the proposed Judicial Arbitration
Court, Good Offices, Mediation and
Commissions of Inquiry, as treated
in the "Conventions for the Pacific
Settlement of International Disputes"* adopted by the first and
second Hague Conferences, and in
the "Draft Convention Relative to
the Creation of a Judicial Arbitration Court"f agreed to by the
second Hague Conference.
Each contestant is requested to
append to his essay a list of works
consulted, if possible with specific
references4
The term "Undergraduate student" applies to one who, in a college or scientific school, is doing
the work prescribed for the degree
of bachelor, or its technical equivalent.
Essays must not exceed 5,000
words (a length of 3,000 is sug7,
geste(i as desirable) and must be
written, pi-eferably in typewriting,
on one side only of plain paper of
ordinary letter size(8xioY) inches).
Manuscripts not easily legible will
not be considered.
Each essay should bear a nom de
' Num(' or arbitrary sign which
Should be included in an accompanying letter giving the writer's
real name, college, class and home
address. Both letter and essay
should reach H. C. Phillips, Secretary Lake Mohonk Conference, Mo*Available in most libraries; also in "Texts
of the Peace Conferences at The Hague," by
James Brown Scott. Ginn & Co., Boston, pp. 2145 155-'93,
113P. 141-154 of Mr. Scott's book (note *); Lake
Vlohonk Conference report, 1910, pp. 229-234.
Wrtie American Peace Society,Washington,D.C.,
thshes a free list of inexpensive references.

honk Lake, N. Y., not later than
March 15, 1912. Essays should be
mailed flat (not rolled).
The award of tlie* prize will be
made at the Lake Mohonk Conference in May, 1912, to which the
winner will be invited.
For additional information, references, etc., address the Secretary
of the Conference.
A similar prize in 1910-ii brought
out sixty-one essays from colleges
in all parts of the United States.
The prize was won by Harry Posner, of West Point, Miss., a student
in the Mississippi Agricultural and
Mechanical College. Mr. Posner's
essay is printed in the 1911 report
of the Conference. Next in order
of merit were the essays of Eugene
M. Kayden (University of Colorado), Lindsay Rogers(Johns Hopkins University), Seymour P. Gilbert, Jr. (Rutgers College), and

THE NEWS LET:ER
VOL. XVI, NO. 2.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 16, 1911.

WEDDING BELLS FOR LYNN

HAZING IS ON THE WANE

Popular Hopkins Football Coach to Be
Married on Saturday—McCabe
and Stollenwerck Ushers.

Sophomores Are Treating the Freshmen
Kindly—Latter Wear Hats and
Ride in Elevator.

Successful in the game of love,
as well as in football, Thomas Herbert Lynn, Yale, '09, will lead to
altar Miss Myra Kincaid McCormick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Seth Thomas McCormick,on Saturday night, October 21, at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Williamsport,
Pa. A reception will follow immediately after the wedding ceremony at the city home of the bride's
parents in Williamsport.
Hopkins football players, in particular, and all Hopkins students,
in general, are interested in this
wedding, because of Mr. Lynn's
connection with Hopkins during
the last two years in the. capacity
of coach of the football team. Coach
Lynn was chosen by the Athletic
Board in the spring of 1910 to succeed Mr. Gill as head coach of the
football team. He was ,highly
recommended to the University by
Walter Camp, the dean of American football, and Ted Coy, the captain of teh Yale championship team
of 1909.
Coach Lynn was a member of the
Yale 'Varsity squad for three years,
and was considered one of the most
reliable and one of the headiest of
the Yale players. The Yale coaches
had unbounded confidence in him.
When he assumed the direction of
the Hopkins team last fall, prospects were not over bright, but
with the assistance of Dr. Paul
Sieber, he succeeded in turning out
the best eleven that ever represented
the Black and Blue on the gridiron.
Although many of last year's men
Will not play this season, Coach
Lynn is hard at work, and before
the home games come round, he
can be depended upon to have a
team on the field which will be able
1. to uphold the reputations made by
the .teams of the last two seasons.
Miss McCormick is a "darling,
and just the sweetest thing that
ever lived," according to stray remarks dropped by Coach Lynn from
time to time. He even goes to the
extent of praising her in foreign
languages and was heard once to
exclaim: "Ciel est toi," as he licked
a postage stamp on the envelope
of a letter to his future better half.
Miss 1\ICormick is a graduate of
the Ogontz School, of Philadelphia,
Pa. Her -family is well known in
Northern Pennsylvania, and her
father is one of the leading lawyers
of the State.

With the exception of one or two
attempts to make the underclassmen sing and practice yells, the
sophomores have so far kept in the
background, and there has been
little real hazing. On Wednesday,
a brief concert, which was interrupted by the appearance of the
police, was given on Howard street
and on Thursday, rumor had it, that
several freshies were taken to a
back yard in the vicinity of the University and turned into scrubwomen.
Both were very harmless forms of
discipline.
But meanwhile, contrary to all
Hopkins traditions, the freshmen
wear their hats in McCoy Hall,
ride in the elevator and swagger
around with senior-like assurance.
There has not even been a classrush to dampen their boyish affrontery.
The musical program which was
given on Wednesday at noon, was.
brief but excellent. Six of the biggist freshmen in the class were
taken to the curbstone in front of
the buildings of the Geological
Survey, on'
Howard street, divested
of their coats and hats, given song
books and told to warble. They
warbled obediently and soon a large
crowd gathered. Two policemen,
who were at the corner of Franklin
and Howard streets, saw the commotion and heard the noise. They
started for the scene, but when they
arrived, the prisoners had been hurried around on Monument street,
where a further program was rendered. This, according to some accounts, was unsatisfactory, and as
a consequence, the offending freshmen were ducked in the fountain.
The, scrubbing stunt took place
on Thursday. The three freshmen
'who were captured, were made to
don aprons and scrub. When they
had concluded their tasks, the sophomores formed themselves into
a mock faculty and awarded degrees, implying proficiency in the

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 16, 1911
Lacrosse Relations With Mount
Washington.

In another column, THE NEwsLETTER prints today a letter in
which the writer urges that the
lacrosse management arrange a
game with Mount Washington and
advances many reasons why such a
contest would be for the best interests of lacrosse in Baltimore, besides providing one of the best
drawing cards and money makers
of the season.
Our experience in games with
Mount Washington in the past has
not been the best and a great deal
of ill-feeling between the adherents
Of the two teams has been shown.
Recent overtures, however, on the
part of the members of the Mount
Washington team, make it seem
probable that if a game were ar• ranged for this year different conditions would exist. At any rate,
when the Hopkins management is
making up its schedule, it would
do no. harm, and a great deal of
good, to talk with representatives
of the Hillmen, and if the game
were tried this year as an experiment, with the understanding that
'if ill-feeling developed, there would
never be another contest, the students and club-men would be on
their guard against any hostile
demonstrations on the field.
We invite expressions of opinion
on the subject.
Have the Class-Rush at Homewood.

- Up until last year, one of the exciting features of the first few days
at Hopkins was the annual classrush between the freshmen and
sophomores, which was held in the
University cage, under the direction
of a committee of seniors. The
time for the fracas was announced,
and freshmen and sophomores,large
and small, were herded in the cage,
and given time to don suitable
clothes. Then each class was lined

up on opposite ends of the track,
and at the given signal, there was
the rush, the ensuing rough-house
and 'the flush of victory for one
class.
Sometimes the ground was covered with. tan-bark; Sometimes
not, and then there was more fun.
The faculty and non-interested students used to stand in the gallery
to see the fray, and class-spirit had
an opportunity to show itself in
a mild and good-natured fashion.
That the rush must be held during
the first week, was one of Hopkins'
traditions.
Last year, however, the University authorities, with a certain amount
of justification, decided that the
cage was too small and the risk
of injury too great. Accordingly,
Homewood was decided upon, and
the two classes clashed between the
halves of a football game.
The same thing should be done
this year. Saturday, October 21, the
date for the game with the Maryland Agricultural College, is a good
time, and it should be arranged for
the rush to take place then. It
would be an excellent feature to
draw a crowd to see the game, and
would be following the precedent
set last year.
THF: NMS-LETTER suggests that
the football management and the
class presidents get together and
see if whether this plan is not feasible.

BALTIMORE, Oct.
To the Editor of THE

12, 1911.

NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—THE NEWS-LETTER has
been doing good work in the past,
and no doubt will continue to do
good work in time to come. However, I think that it might be well
to remind the readers that a college paper can be more successful
if they would send, from time to
time, friendly criticisms and suggestions to the editors. Certainly
the editors would take the criticisms
as they are intended, and endeavor
to* carry out all good suggestions.
I do not intend simply to make
this suggestion and then fail "to
practice what I preach." It has
often occurred to me that THE
NEWS-LETTER, early in the football
season, might run in short accounts
of the new men out for the team.
All of us would like to know what
teams the new graduate and medical men played on formerly, what
they did, etc. Because of such
knowledge, those attending the University would be able to watch the
games with greater interest, since
they would be acquainted with the

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 16, 1911.
ESSAY PRIZES OFFERED
Opportunity for Students Who Are Interested in International Arbitration.
Rogers Third Last Year.

Announcement. is made by the
Lake Mohonk Conference on International Arbitration, that a prize
of $mo is offered for the best essay
on "International Arbitration," by
an _undergraduate man student of
any college or university in the
United States or Canada. This is
the contest which was won by Mr.
L. B., Bobbitt, A.B., 1911,two years
ago. It is given by Mr. Chester
Dewitt Pugsley, of Peekskill, N. Y.
(Harvard, '09). The judges this
year are: Hon. Oscar S. Straus,
member of the Hague Court, formerly ambassador to Turkey; Hon.
Elmer Ellsworth Brown, Chancellor of New York University, and
Rear-Admiral Charles H. Stockton,
1.nited States Navy, retired.
The contest closes March 15,
1912. The following conditions are
announced :
Each essay should show an understanding of the nature and history
of international arbitration apart
from and in connection with the
Hague Cohferences and Hague
Court, and may also refer to (or,
'subject to the above requirement,
emphasize) such subjects as the
Permanent Court of Arbitration,
the proposed Judicial Arbitration
Court, Good Offices, Mediation and
Commissions of Inquiry, as treated
in the "Conventions for the Pacific
Settlement of International Disputes"* adopted by the first and
second Hague Conferences, and in
the "Draft Convention Relative to
the Creation of a Judicial Arbitration Court"f agreed to by the
second Hague Conference.
Each contestant is requested to
append to his essay a list of works
consulted, if possible with specific
references4
The term "Undergraduate student" applies to one who, in a college or scientific school, is doing
the work prescribed for the degree
of bachelor, or its technical equivalent.
Essays must not exceed 5,000
words (a length of 3,000 is sug7,
geste(i as desirable) and must be
written, pi-eferably in typewriting,
on one side only of plain paper of
ordinary letter size(8xioY) inches).
Manuscripts not easily legible will
not be considered.
Each essay should bear a nom de
' Num(' or arbitrary sign which
Should be included in an accompanying letter giving the writer's
real name, college, class and home
address. Both letter and essay
should reach H. C. Phillips, Secretary Lake Mohonk Conference, Mo*Available in most libraries; also in "Texts
of the Peace Conferences at The Hague," by
James Brown Scott. Ginn & Co., Boston, pp. 2145 155-'93,
113P. 141-154 of Mr. Scott's book (note *); Lake
Vlohonk Conference report, 1910, pp. 229-234.
Wrtie American Peace Society,Washington,D.C.,
thshes a free list of inexpensive references.

honk Lake, N. Y., not later than
March 15, 1912. Essays should be
mailed flat (not rolled).
The award of tlie* prize will be
made at the Lake Mohonk Conference in May, 1912, to which the
winner will be invited.
For additional information, references, etc., address the Secretary
of the Conference.
A similar prize in 1910-ii brought
out sixty-one essays from colleges
in all parts of the United States.
The prize was won by Harry Posner, of West Point, Miss., a student
in the Mississippi Agricultural and
Mechanical College. Mr. Posner's
essay is printed in the 1911 report
of the Conference. Next in order
of merit were the essays of Eugene
M. Kayden (University of Colorado), Lindsay Rogers(Johns Hopkins University), Seymour P. Gilbert, Jr. (Rutgers College), and
Charles Schwencke(Brigham Young
University). Mr. John Sharpe Dickinson's essay was given seventh .
place.
Ici on Pane Anglais.
(A crusade has been started in Paris
against the use of foreign words, especially English, in French.)
I'd never been in France before,
Or heard the natives speak.
And so I thought I'd run across
And spend a quiet week.
I saw a Frenchman standing mar
On landing at the dock;
"Queue heure est-il, Monsieur?" I asked,
He answered, "Fiv' o'clock."
Down in the Bois I found a crowd
Collected in a batch.
I .asked them, "'Qu'est cc que c'est que
ca?"
• They told me "football match."
They've "cricket records," "tennis,"
"golf,"
And "rowing," "turf," and "hockey,"
"Paddocks" and "bookmakers" a n d
"bets."
The "trainer" and the "jockey."
And after staying just a week—
Of this I've made a note—
The only words of French I've learned
Are "chic" and "table d'hote."
